channel.title: WSJ.com: Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright © Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: U.S. Pending-Home Sales Fall Unexpectedly
item.description: The number of homes going under contract in the U.S. slipped unexpectedly in December, according to a monthly index.
item.dc:creator: Don Nico Forbes

item.title: EU Lawmakers Ask for Legal Opinion on South America Trade Deal
item.description: The European Parliament narrowly voted on Wednesday to send the bloc’s deal with Mercosur countries to the Court of Justice of the EU for a judicial review.
item.dc:creator: Edith Hancock

item.title: Indonesia’s Central Bank Holds as Rupiah, Policy Worries Mount
item.description: Indonesia’s central bank kept interest rates unchanged again in its first policy meeting of the year, a decision that comes as the rupiah slides to new lows and concerns mount over the country’s fiscal outlook.
item.dc:creator: Ying Xian Wong

item.title: Google searches for “No Buy January” have hit a five-year high as Gen Zers and millennials sign up for the thrifty challenge
item.description: Google searches for “No Buy January” have hit a five-year high as Gen-Zers and Millennials sign up for the thrifty challenge.
item.dc:creator: Laura Cooper

item.title: U.K. Inflation Rose More Than Expected at End of 2025
item.description: The annual rate of consumer-price inflation was 3.4% in December, up from 3.2% in November, the first increase since July.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: President Trump issued an executive order on Tuesday laying out steps to stop Wall Street home purchases
item.description: President issued an executive order on Tuesday that laid out steps to stop Wall Street home purchases.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Picciotto

item.title: BOJ Likely to Take a Breather as It Gauges Impact of Last Hike
item.description: The Bank of Japan is likely to hold policy settings steady this week as it examines the effects of its latest interest-rate hike in December.
item.dc:creator: Megumi Fujikawa

item.title: Escalating tensions over Greenland are supercharging a dynamic that was already under way: a shift in the world economic order that had put the U.S. at the center of the global economy
item.description: The U.S. has long been a beacon of safety when uncertainty reigns. That is changing.
item.dc:creator: Sam Goldfarb

item.title: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent delivered his most pointed public critique of Fed Chair Jerome Powell to date
item.description: The Treasury secretary who previously urged Trump not to fire the Fed chair is now publicly building the case against him.
item.dc:creator: Nick Timiraos

item.title: U.S. to Press Ahead With EU Trade Deal Despite Opposition, Bessent Says
item.description: The Treasury Secretary said he expects to proceed with the agreement, despite some European Union lawmakers saying they might put it on hold over Trump’s Greenland comments.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Market Reaction to Greenland Tensions Has Been Muted, BOE’s Bailey Says
item.description: Bailey said markets were less volatile than might have been expected, but added policymakers must keep a close eye on developments.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Heard on the Street: Conflicting interests make it hard for policymakers to give young Americans a leg up in a brutal housing market
item.description: Young Americans need home prices to fall. Existing owners don’t want to take a hit.
item.dc:creator: Carol Ryan

item.title: Wednesday’s Supreme Court arguments over whether Trump can fire Fed governor Lisa Cook come amid the president’s broader campaign to bend the central bank to presidential will
item.description: Wednesday’s arguments in the Lisa Cook case come amid a broader Trump campaign to bend the central bank to presidential will.
item.dc:creator: James Romoser

item.title: President Trump’s use of tariffs to annex territory is the logical endpoint of his belief in exploiting American economic leverage, WSJ’s @greg_ip writes
item.description: President Trump’s use of tariffs to annex territory is the logical endpoint of his belief in exploiting American economic leverage.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ip

item.title: President Trump’s bid to annex Greenland and unleash tariffs on several European nations has plunged the trans-Atlantic alliance into crisis. If a trade war breaks out, the U.S. could feel the pain.
item.description: Europe is the U.S.’s biggest trading partner, largest investor and closest financial ally.
item.dc:creator: Sam Goldfarb

item.title: Eurozone Finance Ministers Back Croatia’s Vujcic as Next ECB Vice President
item.description: Boris Vujcic, governor of Croatia’s central bank, was nominated as the next vice president of the European Central Bank, the first step in an overhaul of the executive board.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Americans, not foreigners, are bearing almost the entire cost of U.S. tariffs, according to new research
item.description: New research contradicts President Trump’s claim that foreigners are footing the bill.
item.dc:creator: Tom Fairless

item.title: EU’s Retaliatory Tariffs on U.S. Goods Could Kick in Feb. 7, Official Says
item.description: The EU could implement a currently suspended package of tariffs on some $108 billion of U.S. goods a year.
item.dc:creator: Edith Hancock

item.title: IMF Sees Stronger Growth, but Sounds Warning on Higher Tariffs and AI Correction
item.description: The global economy is set to grow faster than previously expected this year, though could falter if trade barriers rise again and geopolitical conflicts intensify, it said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: U.K. House Prices See Record January Jump as Post-Budget Uncertainty Fades
item.description: Average asking prices rose 2.8%, according to Rightmove data, suggesting market sentiment is rebounding following the volatility sparked by the U.K. budget.
item.dc:creator: Anthony O. Goriainoff

item.title: Economists will tell you that it is a tough time for people entering the job market. They can relate: It is the worst market young economists have faced in memory.
item.description: Newly minted Ph.D.s tend to work for universities, government agencies and big white-collar companies. It’s not a great hiring time for any of them.
item.dc:creator: Justin Lahart

item.title: Inflation slowed over the course of 2025, but Americans remain frustrated that they haven’t seen more relief on prices, particularly at the grocery store
item.description: Gasoline prices are down, but rising grocery costs continue to weigh on consumers.
item.dc:creator: Drew An-Pham

item.title: WSJ reporters in Boston and New Orleans bought the agriculture secretary’s suggested $3 meal
item.description: Reporters in Boston and New Orleans bought the agriculture secretary’s suggested meal.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Thomas

item.title: Unemployment Claims Dropped Last Week
item.description: U.S. jobless claims ticked lower last week, showing that despite weaker hiring, the labor market has continued to avoid a rise in layoffs.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Home sales rose 5.1% in December for the biggest gain in nearly two years, although 2025 as a whole still ranks as one of the worst sales slumps in decades
item.description: Home sales rose 5.1% in December for the biggest gain in nearly two years, although 2025 as a whole still ranks as one of the worst sales slumps in decades.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Friedman

item.title: MAHA, Ozempic, fibermaxxing: Powerful forces are pushing America’s food industry to make what could be the biggest overhaul in decades to supermarket shelves
item.description: Food companies are overhauling brands as they work to ditch artificial dyes or pack protein into their products. New U.S. dietary guidelines could speed up the transformation.
item.dc:creator: Emma Brown

item.title: U.S. New Home Sales Pick Up After Summer, Delayed Data Say
item.description: Sales edged down to 737,000 in October last year, from 738,000 in September, but up from a downwardly revised 711,000 in August.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Global Economy Records Stronger Growth, But Is on Course for a Weak Decade, Says World Bank
item.description: The global economy was set to grow more rapidly than previously expected, but is nonetheless on course for its weakest decade in half a century, according to the bank’s economists.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Eurozone’s Household Saving Rate Declined in Third Quarter
item.description: The eurozone’s saving rate fell in the third quarter of last year, helping support the economy as spending modestly recovered.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: U.K. House Prices Expected to Rise But London Likely to Straggle
item.description: U.K. house prices are expected to rise in 2026, with Scotland and Northern England showing the strongest growth and sales prospects, according to real-estate website Zoopla.
item.dc:creator: Anthony O. Goriainoff

item.title: Hiring sputtered. The unemployment rate rose. 2025 put a decisive end to the hottest job market in a generation. Charts tell the story.
item.description: Hiring sputtered. The unemployment rate rose. 2025 put a decisive end to the hottest job market in a generation.
item.dc:creator: Danny Dougherty

item.title: America’s unemployment rate is low. But so is its job growth. That means many Americans are locked out of stable, full-time jobs, and many are struggling.
item.description: Job hunts are getting desperate for Americans who find themselves locked out of stable, full-time work in a stagnant job market.
item.dc:creator: Te-Ping Chen

item.title: President Trump’s social-media post showed job-creation totals that indirectly revealed information from December’s Bureau of Labor Statistics report
item.description: The social-media post showed job-creation totals that indirectly revealed information from December’s Bureau of Labor Statistics report.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Consumer Sentiment Edges Higher, Michigan Survey Finds
item.description: Consumers’ mood improved slightly in January, yet Americans remain mired in anxiety about affordability and sluggish hiring, the University of Michigan’s latest survey indicated.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Eurozone Economy Posts Stronger Growth on Investment Rebound
item.description: The economy grew at a faster pace than estimated in the three months through September, aided by a pickup in investment.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Growth to Slow as Tariffs Bite, but AI Investments May Cushion the Blow
item.description: The OECD forecast the global economy to expand by 2.9% next year, a slowdown from 3.2% this year.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon
